page.title: 10Disused Quarries
page.content: The closure of the Barnard Castle to Kirkby Stephen railway in{1964}led to the closure of all but one of the remaining quarries.Most of the unused land became grassed over and,although it was rough and uneven,it was in many instances used by the farmers as extra grazing for sheep and fatstock. Whilst the construction of the dual carriageway on the A66 trunk road was to require much imported material,it also demanded convenient places to act as dumps for countless tons of earth, especially from the section at Galley Hill where the former steep gradient was to be drastically reduced. The small disused quarries provided the ideal solution to the problem.Tons of rock,clay and earth were tipped in them.When topsoil and grass seed were then added new agricultural land was created and the environment improved.
